Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: An emergency diversion cuts across three sectors at once, requiring rapid multi-sector coordination.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, half-listening as my family tossed around ideas for the weekend. My younger brother wanted to go hiking, my mom suggested a movie night, and everyone looked to me, expecting I’d be there, too. I nodded, trying to sound enthusiastic, but my phone buzzed in my pocket. The message was urgent: an emergency diversion was coming in, cutting across three sectors. I was needed on the comms, coordinating with other controllers to keep the airspace safe. My mom’s eyes met mine, full of hope that I’d finally join a family outing. At the same time, I felt the weight of responsibility pressing from the other side—lives depended on my focus and quick decisions. My heart pounded as I tried to balance the warmth of my family’s expectations with the cold, immediate demands of my job. I could feel myself being pulled in two directions, each one impossible to ignore.
